prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC1140 13CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will image the central field of NGC1140 in the 13CO(2-1) isotopologue.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The observed spectra (see main proposal text) show velocity structure on the order of 10-20 km/s. The total (quadrature) width of the emission is 50-60 km/s in all transitions observed, so 16 km/s channels should be sufficient to resolve the expected kinematics. Although we have calculated the exposure times with 16 km/s channels, we will perform the observations with 5 km/s channels, so that we can explore the velocity structure should the emission be stronger than our conservative estimates.

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. We need to separate the two main knots of super-star clusters (SSCs) in this galaxy which are separated by 3 arcsec, so that our requested beam size will enable us to separate the two main concentrations of SSCs. 1.38 arcsec (130 pc) is the largest resolution achievable in Band 8, so we have designed the observations of the other transitions to have the same resolution.

We have already detected 13CO(2-1) with the IRAM 30m, and detected other CO transitions with IRAM and APEX. Fitting the resulting line intensities with a grid of 24000 RADEX models for the 6 observed CO transitions [12CO(1-0), 12CO(2-1), 12CO(3-2), 12CO(4-3), 13CO(1-0), 13CO(2-1)], we find a filling factor of roughly 0.1% for this transition (with a best-fit RADEX line width of 10 km/s). To be conservative, we assume 10 times this filling factor, and assume 1D beam dilution, appropriate for multi-component velocity structure. Thus, the observed integrated line intensity of 0.150 K.km/s (main-beam temperature units, global quadrature line width roughly 50 km/s for all transitions) translates into 28.3 mK/bm. Since we want a 5-sigma detection, we require a 1-sigma sensitivity of 5.7 mK/bm. We use velocity channels of 16 km/s so that we can grossly resolve the velocity structure in the emission (although we will observe at 5 km/s, and bin in velocity if necessary).

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. Thus we do not require ACA observations to achieve our SG.

The observed spectra (see main proposal text) show velocity structure on the order of 10-20 km/s. The total (quadrature) width of the emission is 50-60 km/s in all transitions observed, so 10 km/s channels should be sufficient to resolve the expected kinematics. Although we have calculated the exposure times with 10 km/s channels, we will perform the observations with 5 km/s channels, so that we can explore the velocity structure should the emission be stronger than our conservative estimates.

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. We need to separate the two main knots of super-star clusters (SSCs) in this galaxy which are separated by 3 arcsec, so that our requested beam size will enable us to separate the two main concentrations of SSCs. 1.38 arcsec (130 pc) is the largest resolution achievable in Band 8, so we have designed the observations of the other transitions to have the same resolution.

We have already detected 12CO(2-1) with the IRAM 30m, and detected other CO transitions with IRAM and APEX. Fitting the resulting line intensities with a grid of 24000 RADEX models for the 6 observed CO transitions [12CO(1-0), 12CO(2-1), 12CO(3-2), 12CO(4-3), 13CO(1-0), 13CO(2-1)], we find a filling factor of roughly 1.6% for this transition (with a best-fit RADEX line width of 10 km/s). To be conservative, we assume 5 times this filling factor, and assume 1D beam dilution, appropriate for multi-component velocity structure. Thus, the observed integrated line intensity of 1.82 K.km/s (main-beam temperature units, global quadrature line width roughly 50 km/s for all transitions) translates into 50 mK/bm. Since we want a 5-sigma detection, we require a 1-sigma sensitivity of 10 mK/bm, with velocity channels of 10 km/s so that we can detect the velocity structure in the emission (although will observe with 5 km/s channels).

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. Thus we do not require ACA observations to achieve our SG.

The observed spectra (see main proposal text) show velocity structure on the order of 10-20 km/s. The total (quadrature) width of the emission is 50-60 km/s in all transitions observed, so 16 km/s channels should be sufficient to resolve the expected kinematics. Although we have calculated the exposure times with 16 km/s channels, we will perform the observations with 5 km/s channels, so that we can explore the velocity structure should the emission be stronger than our conservative estimates.

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions is able to reproduce the [CI](1-0)/CO(1-0) observed ratio and gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. We need to separate the two main knots of super-star clusters (SSCs) in this galaxy which are separated by 3 arcsec, so that our requested beam size will enable us to separate the two main concentrations of SSCs. 1.38 arcsec (130 pc) is the largest resolution achievable in Band 8.

We have already detected [CI](1-0) with APEX (see main text), and detected six CO transitions with IRAM and APEX. Fitting the resulting CO line intensities with a grid of 24000 RADEX models for the 6 observed CO transitions [12CO(1-0), 12CO(2-1), 12CO(3-2), 12CO(4-3), 13CO(1-0), 13CO(2-1)], gives an estimated [CI]/CO(1-0) ratio consistent with what we measure for [CI], and a filling factor of roughly 4% for CI (with a RADEX line width of 10 km/s). We assume this filling factor, and also 1D beam dilution, appropriate for multi-component velocity structure in the other transitions. Thus, the observed integrated line intensity of 0.012 K.km/s (main-beam temperature units, global quadrature line width roughly 50 km/s for all transitions) translates into 36 mK/bm. Since we want a 5-sigma detection, we require a 1-sigma sensitivity of 7.3 mK/bm, with 16 km/s velocity channels. We use velocity channels of 16 km/s so that we can grossly resolve the velocity structure in the emission (although we will observe at 5 km/s, and bin in velocity).

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. Thus we do not require ACA observations to achieve our SG.

The observed spectra (see main proposal text) show velocity structure on the order of 10-20 km/s. The total width of the emission is 50-60 km/s in all transitions observed. Given that we want the Band 6 observations to be performed at 5 km/s resolution, even though we have calculated our time estimates with 10 km/s channels, we will be able to explore the velocity structure in Band 7 at 3.4 km/s resolution should the emission be stronger than our conservative estimates.

The RADEX best-fit model of 6 detected CO transitions gives a source size of 22 arcsec; the optical size of the galaxy is larger than this, but we are not interested in the total flux, but rather the morphology and kinematics of the molecular emission. We need to separate the two main knots of super-star clusters (SSCs) in this galaxy which are separated by 3 arcsec, so that our requested beam size will enable us to separate the two main concentrations of SSCs. 1.38 arcsec (130 pc) is the largest resolution achievable in Band 8, so we have designed the observations of the other transitions to have the same resolution.

We have already detected 12CO(3-2) with APEX, and detected other CO transitions with IRAM and APEX. Fitting the resulting line intensities with a grid of 24000 RADEX models for the 6 observed CO transitions [12CO(1-0), 12CO(2-1), 12CO(3-2), 12CO(4-3), 13CO(1-0), 13CO(2-1)], we find a filling factor of roughly 1.2% for this transition (with a best-fit RADEX line width of 10 km/s). To be conservative, we assume 5 times this filling factor (and 1D beam dilution, appropriate for multi-component velocity structure). Thus, the observed integrated line intensity of 1.16 K.km/s (main-beam temperature units, global quadrature line width roughly 50 km/s for all transitions) translates into 29.8 mK/bm. Since we want a 5-sigma detection, we require a 1-sigma sensitivity of 6 mK/bm, with velocity channels of 10 km/s so that we can detect the velocity structure in the emission. We will observe this transition with channels of 3.4 km/s, and bin in velocity if necessary.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Feedback from accreting black holes and from massive stars and supernovae has acquired a fundamental role for our understanding of galaxy evolution. However, there are currently few observational constraints for stellar feedback in sub-luminous metal-poor galaxies. We propose to observe a low-metallicity starburst, NGC1140, which harbors a population of young, massive, super-star clusters (SSCs) in order to assess the effects of stellar feedback around these extreme objects. We propose to map at 130pc (1.4 arcsec) scales four transitions: 12CO(2-1), 12CO(3-2), 13CO(2-1), and [CI](1-0) in order to fully characterize the molecular gas in this metal-poor interstellar medium (ISM), and constrain the fraction of carbon in the ionized (with [CII] from Herschel), molecular, and atomic phases. We will compare our results with recent models for molecular hydrogen formation and better quantify the effects of stellar feedback for input to galaxy evolution models. ALMA will provide an observational perspective on the effects of stellar feedback in an extreme environment which may be representative of the ISM in high-redshift galaxy populations.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional
Department of Physics, Cambridge, University of
